title.justification: This is the title of the paper.

extractions.description: The paper introduces Stochastic GFlowNets, an algorithm that extends Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets) to stochastic environments, overcoming limitations of existing GFlowNets which are limited to deterministic environments. Through extensive experiments on benchmark tasks with stochastic dynamics, the paper demonstrates that Stochastic GFlowNets offer significant advantages over standard GFlowNets as well as Monte Carlo Markov Chain (MCMC) and Reinforcement Learning (RL) methods.

type.justification: The paper presents extensive experimental results and comparisons to demonstrate the effectiveness of Stochastic GFlowNets.
type.quote: Through extensive experiments on benchmark tasks with stochastic dynamics, the paper demonstrates that Stochastic GFlowNets offer significant advantages over standard GFlowNets as well as Monte Carlo Markov Chain (MCMC) and Reinforcement Learning (RL) methods.

name.justification: The primary contribution of the paper is in extending Generative Flow Networks for more general stochastic environments, which falls under Probabilistic Modeling.
name.quote: Generative Flow Networks (or GFlowNets for short) are a family of probabilistic agents that learn to sample complex combinatorial structures through the lens of “inference as control”.

name.justification: The paper relates GFlowNets to reinforcement learning and contrasts its approach to typical reinforcement learning methods.
name.quote: The sequential process of generating an object following a policy bears a close resemblance to reinforcement learning [RL; Sutton and Barto, 2018].

name.justification: The paper positions GFlowNets in the context of generative models and their ability to generate diverse and high-quality samples.
name.quote: GFlowNets aim to learn a stochastic policy for sampling composite objects x with probability proportional to the reward function R(x)....This is desirable in many real-world tasks where the diversity of solutions is important.

name.justification: GFlowNets and their evaluated baselines include Monte Carlo Markov Chain methods.
name.quote: GFlowNets learn policies to generate objects x ∈ X sequentially, and are related to Monte-Carlo Markov chain (MCMC) methods [Metropolis et al., 1953, Hastings, 1970, Andrieu et al., 2003].

name.justification: Stochastic GFlowNet is the primary contribution of this paper, extending GFlowNets to tackle stochastic environments.
name.quote: To overcome this challenge, this paper introduces Stochastic GFlowNets, a new algorithm that extends GFlowNets to stochastic environments.

is_contributed.justification: The primary novelty and contribution of the paper is the introduction of Stochastic GFlowNet.
is_contributed.quote: In summary, the contribution of this work is as follows: • We propose a novel method, Stochastic GFlowNet, which is the first empirically effective approach extending GFlowNets to the more general stochastic environments based on Bengio et al. [2021b].

is_executed.justification: The model was empirically tested with experiments on benchmark tasks.
is_executed.quote: Through extensive experiments on benchmark tasks with stochastic dynamics, the paper demonstrates that Stochastic GFlowNets offer significant advantages over standard GFlowNets as well as MCMC- and RL-based approaches.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares Stochastic GFlowNet with standard GFlowNets and methods like MCMC and RL-based approaches.
is_compared.quote: Extensive experimental results demonstrate that Stochastic GFlowNets offer significant advantages over standard GFlowNets as well as MCMC- and RL-based approaches.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references foundational work on GFlowNets on which this extension is based.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Existing work on GFlowNets [Bengio et al., 2021a, Malkin et al., 2022a, Madan et al., 2022], however, is limited to deterministic environments.

name.justification: The GridWorld environment was used to conduct a series of experiments to test the effectiveness of Stochastic GFlowNets.
name.quote: We first conduct a series of experiments in the GridWorld task introduced in Bengio et al. [2021a] to understand the effectiveness of Stochastic GFlowNets.

referenced_paper_title.value: Flow network based generative models for non-iterative diverse candidate generation.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper is where the GridWorld task used in this study was initially introduced.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We first conduct a series of experiments in the GridWorld task introduced in Bengio et al. [2021a] to understand the effectiveness of Stochastic GFlowNets.

name.justification: The TF Bind 8 dataset was used to evaluate the performance of Stochastic GFlowNets on generating DNA sequences with high binding activity.
name.quote: We now consider the practical task of generating DNA sequences with high binding activity with particular transcription factors, following Jain et al. [2022a].

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper used the same dataset and followed the setup from the referenced work.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We now consider the practical task of generating DNA sequences with high binding activity with particular transcription factors, following Jain et al. [2022a].

name.justification: The AMP dataset was used to evaluate the task of generating peptide sequences with antimicrobial properties.
name.quote: In this section, we study the realistic task of generating peptide sequences with anti-microbial properties [Malkin et al., 2022a, Jain et al., 2022a].

referenced_paper_title.justification: The AMP dataset used in this study is the same as the one used in the referenced paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In this section, we study the realistic task of generating peptide sequences with anti-microbial properties [Malkin et al., 2022a, Jain et al., 2022a].
